stance1: we should embrace genetic engineering to enhance human capabilities
stance2: we should let natural evolution take its course without interference
userstance1: I believe we should actively pursue genetic engineering to enhance human capabilities. This would allow us to eliminate genetic diseases, increase intelligence, and extend human lifespan. With proper regulation and ethical guidelines, we could create a healthier, more capable human race that's better equipped to face future challenges. The benefits far outweigh the risks, and we have a moral obligation to use our scientific knowledge to improve humanity.
userstance2: I strongly believe we should let natural evolution take its course without interference. Genetic engineering could lead to unintended consequences and create a dangerous divide between enhanced and non-enhanced humans. Nature has worked for millions of years to create the perfect balance, and our attempts to improve upon it could have disastrous effects. We should focus on improving our environment and society rather than altering our fundamental biology.
response1: Genetic engineering holds immense promise—eradicating heritable disease, boosting resilience, perhaps even extending healthy life-span. Yet the same power carries serious risks: unforeseen health effects, new inequities, loss of genetic diversity, and the temptation to define “better” in narrow, shifting ways. Progress therefore shouldn’t mean rushing to enhancement, but moving cautiously: prioritize treating or preventing clear harms; demand rigorous safety data; keep decisions transparent, globally inclusive, and governed by rules that prevent coercion or widening social gaps. In short, use the technology, but let humility and equity guide every step.
response2: Natural evolution will always continue, but human-guided changes are now unavoidable (vaccines, medicine, selective breeding of crops, etc.). The question is not whether we intervene, but how wisely we do so. Carefully regulated, therapy-focused genetic engineering—aimed at preventing severe disease rather than boosting status traits—can alleviate suffering without creating a “genetic elite.” The priority should be robust oversight, equity of access, and humility about what we don’t yet understand. In short: cautious, therapeutic use—yes; unrestrained enhancement—no.

Let robots take on tasks that are truly dangerous, exhausting, or impossibly precise for humans, while we redesign work so people still direct, oversee, and benefit from what robots do. That preserves safety and productivity without sacrificing the human purpose, income, and connection you value.

Right now, the empirical evidence fits the emergence story best, but until we have a complete explanatory bridge from neural dynamics to first-person experience, the fundamental-property hypothesis can’t be definitively ruled out. Personally, I lean toward emergence while staying agnostic enough to watch for a deeper theory that could unify both perspectives.
response2:

So, while the pan-cosmic view isn’t logically impossible, neuroscience and cognitive science keep accumulating results that fit well with consciousness as an emergent, information-integrating process in complex biological (and potentially artificial) systems. I therefore lean toward emergence, pending data that would force us to expand the ontology.

• The directionality of time tracks the growth of entropy rather than any built-in asymmetry of the dynamical laws.

• Neuroscience shows our perception of a smooth “now” is an active construction of the brain.

2. Quantum-gravity scale  
• Many candidate theories (loop quantum gravity, causal-set theory, AdS/CFT, tensor-network models) hint that spacetime—including time—may arise from deeper, non-spatiotemporal structures such as quantum entanglement or discrete causal links. Here time would be emergent.

3. Human level  
• Our psychological “flow” of time, and its one-way arrow, stem from entropy increase, memory formation and biological rhythms—clearly emergent features.

So: time behaves as a fundamental coordinate for most practical physics, yet it may itself emerge from more primitive quantum information. Your sense of its fluidity is consistent with both relativity and the possibility that what feels fundamental to us is, at root, derivative.
